swarmsim.Utils.control_utils module#

swarmsim.Utils.control_utils.compute_distances(positions_1, positions_2)[source]#
swarmsim.Utils.control_utils.gaussian_input(x, y, A=5.0, mu_x=0.0, mu_y=0.0, sigma_x=1.0, sigma_y=1.0)[source]#

This method, given the parametes of a Gaussin and some points where to evaluate the function, computes a 2D Gaussian distribution. Assumption: the covariance matrix is diagonal :param A (float): :type A (float): Maximum amplitude of the signal :param mu_x(float): :type mu_x(float): Average on the first dimension :param mu_y(float): :type mu_y(float): Average on the second dimension :param sigma_x(float): :type sigma_x(float): Standard deviation in the first dimension :param sigma_y(float): :type sigma_y(float): Standard deviation in the second dimension

Function to print information

swarmsim.Utils.logger_utils.append_txt(log_name, current_info)[source]#
swarmsim.Utils.logger_utils.append_csv(log_name, current_info)[source]#
swarmsim.Utils.logger_utils.save_npz(log_name, data)[source]#

A function to save multiple tensors in a single .npz file to store relevant data.

Parameters:

  • log_name (string of the .npz output name)

  • data (dict of {name_tensor: value} where name_tensor is a string and value is np.array)

Returns:

None

Notes

Create numpy arrays of the data to save and add them to a dictionary. Once saved, access the .npz with the field corresponding to the name used.

Examples

settling_times = np.array([1,2,3,4,5]) control_efforts = np.array([6,7,8,9,10]) data = {‘settling_time’:settling_times, ‘control_efforts’:control_efforts} logger.save_data(‘my_data.npz’, data)

data_loaded = np.load(‘pathmy_data.npz’) settling_times_ = data_loaded[‘settling_times’] control_efforts_ = data_loaded[‘control_efforts’]
